items.title: Cardinal branded modules break the functionality of stoermelder's STRIP
items.body:
STRIP from stoermelder can be used for bypassing all the adjacent modules to the left or right with a press of a button. (For this to work, all the modules have to be right next to each other.)

In Cardinal v22.12 (LV2) running under Arch Linux, if one of the adjacent modules has the Cardinal brand, all the other modules beyond that one will be ignored when I click on the 'Switch strip off' or 'Switch/toggle strip on'.

Here's a screencast demonstrating the issue. In each row, I added STRIP, some random modules, and in certain rows, I also placed Cardinal Host MIDI or Cardinal Host MIDI CC somewhere between them.

(The only change I made to the settings of STRIP is that I set the Port/Switch On mode to _Toggle_ in its context menu, so you can see me click on a single button instead of two, which would be the default behaviour.)

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10419911/210411797-143977d5-bc23-4f1a-81fc-4136f6b85878.mp4

- Row 1: All adjacent modules are bypassed correctly.
- Rows 2 and 3: Here Host MIDI is added. Everything until Host MIDI is bypassed, but nothing else.
- Row 4: All is working correctly here.
- Row 5: Host MIDI CC is added. The two modules left of Host MIDI CC are ignored.

Another interesting observation is that although the text module also has the DISTRHO/Cardinal brand, it doesn't affect the behaviour of STRIP in any way.

items.title: Add Sapphire Elastika to Cardinal?
items.body:
I would like to submit my [Sapphire](https://github.com/cosinekitty/sapphire) plugin, particularly its module [Elastika](https://github.com/cosinekitty/sapphire/blob/main/Elastika.md), as a candidate for inclusion in Cardinal. Elastika was recently featured in a [video by Omri Cohen](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DEoMeNHOVgE), and with the resulting attention, people are starting to ask me if it can be added to Cardinal. So here I am.

Some quick facts:

* Sapphire is licensed GPLv3+.
* It uses a few very simple knob and slider graphics that would have to be replaced for licensing reasons. Hopefully this is minor.
* All other artwork in the panel design falls under GPLv3+.

I will be happy to do as much of the porting work as would be helpful. I already have Cardinal building and running on my Linux system, and I'm reading the developer documentation now. I just wanted to post this issue to find out if a pull request would be welcomed, or is there another route to including a new module in Cardinal?

Thank you!

items.title: VST3 version not reported correctly in Steinberg Cubase
items.body:
The VST3 SDK version information is being reported in Cubase (10.5.30, 11.0.41 an 12.0.52) as "Travesty 3.7.4" rather than "VST 3.7.4" which means that the plugin is not listed as a VST3 plugin in the Cubase plugin insert menus and is also captured in their exported plugin information as "Other Plugins" rather than "VST3 Plugins". 

Having tested on other hosts (Cakewalk, Cantabile 4, Gig Performer 4.5, VST Live and WaveLab) it seems to be very specific to the way Cubase uses this information, but it does make it confusing using Cardinal in Cubase, and maybe could cause issues when Steinberg remove VST2 support in the future, depending on how they identify acceptable VST3 plugins.

items.title: Unexpected behavior on sample delay modules
items.body:
Version 22.11

When using Grande's SampleDelays, VarSampleDelays and Bacon Music's SampleDelay there is the same unexpected, but consistent, behavior.

I measured the samples by recording the stereo audio with the left channel having the original signal (for example, a trigger) and the right channel connected to the delayed signal with the delay module (or more of the same delay module chained together), and then confronted the samples.

When setting a sample delay module to n samples, it actually behaves like it is set to n - 1 samples.
So, setting the delay to 1 (or connecting a cable to the +1 on Grande's SampleDelays) it makes no delay, setting to 2 (connecting a cable to the +2 on Grande's SampleDelays) it makes a delay of 1 sample, and so on.

I tested the modules with different sample rates (to be precise, on 48000 Hz and 192000 Hz in the corresponding Jack session), on Cardinal Jack standalone and as a plugin (I tested the plugin version through Ardour), both on Windows and Linux, the behavior is consistent.

I also tested the same modules on VCV Rack, and they behave correctly.

items.title: feat: add example patch with a classic subtractive polysynth setup
items.body:
# A classic polyphonic 2-oscillator synthesizer

* 2 VCOs with blendable sawtooth and pulse waves
* 1 multi-mode filter
* 1 filter envelope
* 1 VCA envelope
* 1 multi-waveform LFO

Notes:

* The LFO is patched to oscillator pitch by default.
  The amount can be controlled via the 2A and 2B level
  knobs of the "Matrix44" mixer module.
* You can control additional destinations with the LFO by 
  patching its output(s) into the "Matrix44" module's input 
  (optionally via the "8Vert" attenuator module) and
  then the outputs of the "Matrix44" module into the 
  destinations. Then use its corresponding level knobs to 
  control the amount.
* The pitch bend amount can be controlled via the 3A and 3B
  level knobs of the "Matrix44" module (3.5% is roughly 2
  semitones).
* The number of polyphonic voices can be set via the 
  context menu of the "Cardinal Host MIDI" module.

items.title: Order modules according to cable connections
items.body:
Hello!

This PR allows the `internal->modules` to be ordered according to their cable connections, and not to the order in which they were created.

WIth this, there is now a guarantee that no single sample feedback is introduced between cable connections, unless feedback connections are in place.

As an example, this is a simple patch that plays a sine wave through a sequence of 54 modules to measure the difference of the starting signal with the end one. As you can see, with the current implementation there is definitely a delay introduced by the connections, since the audio process steps through the `modules` in regards of the order in which they were created, ignoring which modules should come first according to the cable connections:

![Screenshot_20221101_003217](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/32070555/199129543-19aab15f-1e6a-4411-b8f8-2157d3e2f521.png)

On the other hand, with this PR, the signal flow is actually showing a null sum between the starting signal and the end one, as we would expect following the cables:

![Screenshot_20221101_004514](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/32070555/199129847-b0dd3e6a-b40c-4162-9a22-c9e20088bb27.png)

As a side result, this PR guarantees that all feedback connections are always only introducing a one sample delay, and not more.

items.body:
Hello! And thanks for the hard work on this, it's super sweet! :) 

So yeah, ODDsound have some modules to use their fantastic MTS-ESP system. Most important of which is their v/oct quantizer. 

If you don't know about the system there's more info on oddsound.com, but long story short: it's a clever open-source standard for managing musical tuning across an entire electronic music environment. 
Every compatible software or hardware instrument connects behind the scenes to a "master" tuning plugin, which can adjust the tuning of all of them simultaneously in real-time.

The previously most established ("micro")tuning workflow was using text files with scale scale and keyboard mapping info. The MTS-ESP system offers two advantages: 1,it saves time to tune all instruments from one central place instead of loading .scl and .kbm files into every single instance. And 2, the tuning of any note in the scale can be adjusted during playback which is very useful and opens up some really interesting creative possibilities.

It'd be great to have the ODDsound modules in Cardinal!

Here's the github repo for the modules: https://github.com/ODDSound/MTS-ESP-VCVRack 
Oli who develops these is usually very happy to answer questions if necessary.

Thanks again!

items.title: Favourites, zoom settings etc not carrying over in instances.
items.body:
In Bitwig loading multiple Cardinal VST's my favourites don't carry across to new instances or previously loaded instances of Cardinal.

Bitwig  4.3.4
Cardinal 22.07

items.title: Previously setup cardinal instances not getting loaded properly on Bitwig.
items.body:
When making a patch and letting bitwig save the patch on load it sometimes doesn't load the patch correctly,  if i reload it often works the second time.

Bitwig  4.3.4
Cardinal 22.07

items.title: Add README to releases artifacts
items.body:
I noticed that during the [Cardinal One Synth Challenge](https://sites.google.com/site/kvrosc/2022/osc-163-cardinal) a common question was: "What are these different plugin versions?".

I suggest adding the README or at least the [Plugin variants section](https://github.com/DISTRHO/Cardinal#plugin-variants) to the build artifacts.

items.title: Huge noise when opening a project
items.body: Platform: Ableton Live 11 on MacOS Monterrey The issue is when you open a saved project on Live that contains any Cardinal Synth (AU or VST3) starts making lot of noise that you only can stop opening the plugin. So you need to be very careful with your speakers/ears when opening a project. When you load a preset of Cardinal Synth in a track same problem happens.

items.title: VST3 Not working in Ableton Live 11 on MacOS
items.body: Cardinal VST3 version is not detected in Ableton 11 as a plugin FX and Synth versions are OK.

items.title: Host Time doesn't send Trigger Signals in Logic Pro 10.7.2
items.body:
Hi, thanks for making this plugin, I really love it ! 

I am encountering the issue that the host Signal isn't sending anything out (the lights are not blinking as well) 
the display is working in time with logic tho. 

Any Idea What it could be ? 

Thanks a lot for your time !

items.title: Headless mode doesn't work
items.body:
It's possible to run the VCV Rack with -h option to run it headless.
If I try to do the same with Cardinal it gives me:
```
nek@raspberrypi:~ $ ./Cardinal -h
Cardinal self-contained executable, based on UnZipSFX
Launching: '/tmp/Cardinal/Cardinal -h'
libjack.so.0 loaded successfully!
[0.000 info CardinalPlugin.cpp:235 Initializer] Cardinal JACK/Standalone v2.1.2

items.title: Add limiter module
items.body:
Something missing in Cardinal.
excerpt from IRC talk, for future reference:

```
00:54 < jtb> Another major thing Cardinal needs is a good limiter, the bogaudio one lets through fairly big peaks even with 0 attack.
00:54 < jtb> I remember you asked what was missing the other day so I've been thinking about that
01:08 < dreamer> find us one
01:08 < falktx> zamaudio has one I think
01:08 < falktx> or we can just reuse x42 dpl plugin in rack
01:09 < falktx> https://x42-plugins.com/x42/x42-limiter
01:10 < x42> would not be the worst idea
01:11 < dreamer> we just need a vertical UI ;)
01:11 < falktx> x42: what is the minimum block size the plugin can run at?
01:12 < x42> 1, but it has latency
01:12 < x42> since it's a look-ahead limiter
01:12 < falktx> that is expected
01:13 < falktx> jtb: note both Rack and Cardinal have a 0dB (-/+1.0f) brickwall limiter on the outputs
01:13 < x42> no idea how well it performs, but the inner loop isn't vectorizable to begin with (there are branches), so it's probably fine.
01:15 < falktx> x42: any parameters are suitable for audio-rate modulation?
01:15 < x42> falktx: there is a "cleaner" implementation at https://github.com/x42/sound-gambit/blob/master/peaklim.cc#L197-L350
01:17 < x42> yes, gain is interpolated. threshold is intentionally not. when you change it you want it to directly hard-limit
01:17 < x42> and release is a time-constant which doesn't need interpolation, since it only indirectly affects the signal
01:18 < falktx> so gain and release can have cv modulation
01:18 < falktx> should put this info in a ticket..
01:18 < x42> in theory so can the threshold. might be interesting
01:19 < x42> that probably results in constrained amplitude modulation. 
01:20 < x42> it's not what you'd usually use a limiter for, but why not?!
```

items.title: Question/Request: Is there a microtonal and polyphonic sequencer or quantizer included in Cardinal?
items.body:
I'm quite new to VCV Rack and was thinking of trying Cardinal, but before I download and try it, I wanted to ask if it has a module like [H4N4 Xen Quantizer](https://library.vcvrack.com/h4n4-modules/xen-qnt), which just quantizes signals polyphonically based on whatever Scala file is loaded into it. I also want to know if Cardinal has a sequencer that can generate notes from Scala files.

If you don't yet, would you be fine with adding the module I mentioned above into Cardinal? It's GPLv3+

Thanks

items.title: Reset issues in drum sequencers
items.body:
Hi,

I have a sync/reset issue with sequencers. It's particulartly obvious with drum sequencers and it varies depending the DAW.
My reset input is always connected to the reset output of the host time module. The BPM seems ok.

With Studio One : Reset is never sharp. There is always a slight delay, sequencers (I tried with Gate-Seq-64 and Drum Sequencer) are not usable.
With Maschine : Reset is in sync with the DAW but with some Sequencers (Gate-Seq-64) the first step is never triggered
With Reaper (unfortunately not my usual DAW...) : It looks fine ! 

Regards.
